reasoning: The critique targets a specific sub-claim in the position’s rebuttal to compute bottlenecks: that near-frontier experiments may be unnecessary because researchers can rely on extrapolation/proxies and because progress hasn’t slowed despite fewer near-frontier runs. That sub-claim supports the broader conclusion, but it’s not the core of the post (which argues via multiple routes that compute complementarity ρ is likely higher / bottlenecks later), so centrality is modest. The critique’s mechanism (adversarial poisoning causing proxy-based epistemic failure) is conceptually coherent and would be relevant if strong adversaries and compromised evaluation channels are in play, but it is highly speculative, does not show that compute bottlenecks themselves bite earlier, and doesn’t directly rebut the main economic/ρ-based argument—at most it introduces an additional, different bottleneck (security/measurement integrity). Hence moderate correctness (plausible but assumption-heavy) and low-to-moderate strength. It is clearly stated, tightly focused, and contains little filler.
title: Reliance on extrapolation creates exploitable adversarial attack surfaces
